verses.text: In the ninth year of Zedekiah’s reign, in the tenth month, on the tenth day of the month, Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon came with all his army against Jerusalem and laid siege to it; and they built siege works all around it.
verses.comment: Restated chronological opening; matches Hebrew text order.

verses.text: So the city was under siege until the eleventh year of King Zedekiah.
verses.comment: Direct reference to the duration of the siege.

verses.text: On the ninth day of the fourth month, the famine in the city became so severe that there was no food for the people of the land.
verses.comment: Notes the severity of the famine; 'people of the land' as in Hebrew.

verses.text: Then a breach was made in the city wall, and all the men of war fled by night by way of the gate between the two walls, which is by the king’s garden. The Chaldeans were all around the city, and the king went toward the plain.
verses.comment: Preserves fleeing route details; 'Chaldeans' for Babylonians per Hebrew.

verses.text: But the army of the Chaldeans pursued the king, and they overtook him in the plains of Jericho. All his army was scattered from him.
verses.comment: 'Plains' as 'Arabah' (Hebrew); 'scattered' matches original.

verses.text: Then they captured the king and brought him up to the king of Babylon at Riblah, and they pronounced judgment on him.
verses.comment: Kept 'judgment' as formal judicial act.

verses.text: They slaughtered the sons of Zedekiah before his eyes, then they put out Zedekiah’s eyes and bound him with bronze chains and took him to Babylon.
verses.comment: Retained grim details per original text.

verses.text: In the fifth month, on the seventh day of the month (which was the nineteenth year of King Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon), Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard, a servant of the king of Babylon, came to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Kept month/day specifics; 'captain of the guard' for 'chief of the executioners'.

verses.text: He burned the house of the LORD, the king’s house, and all the houses of Jerusalem—every great house he burned with fire.
verses.comment: Maintains sequence of destruction; 'house of the LORD' as 'temple.'

verses.text: And all the army of the Chaldeans who were with the captain of the guard broke down the walls around Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Kept active role of army as in Hebrew.

verses.text: Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard carried away into exile the rest of the people who remained in the city, as well as the deserters who defected to the king of Babylon, and the rest of the people.
verses.comment: Distinguished 'remanent' and 'deserters.'

verses.text: But the captain of the guard left some of the poorest people of the land to be vine-dressers and farmers.
verses.comment: 'Poorest' is literal Hebrew; maintained occupational detail.

verses.text: The Chaldeans broke in pieces the bronze pillars that were in the house of the LORD, and the stands and the bronze sea that were in the house of the LORD, and carried the bronze to Babylon.
verses.comment: Expanded for clarity but kept original objects and actions.

verses.text: They also took away the pots, shovels, snuffers, dishes for incense, and all the bronze vessels used in the temple service.
verses.comment: Identifies each vessel by standard translation.

verses.text: The captain of the guard took away the firepans and the bowls, which were of gold and silver.
verses.comment: Clarifies metal content of items.

verses.text: As for the two pillars, the one sea, and the stands which Solomon had made for the house of the LORD, the bronze of all these articles was beyond weight.
verses.comment: Specifies Solomon as maker per original context.

verses.text: The height of one pillar was eighteen cubits, and a capital of bronze was on it; the height of the capital was three cubits; and the latticework and pomegranates, all of bronze, were on the capital all around. The second pillar was like these, with the latticework.
verses.comment: Numbers and feature details as per Hebrew.

verses.text: The captain of the guard took Seraiah the chief priest, Zephaniah the second priest, and the three keepers of the threshold.
verses.comment: Titles and names as in original order.

verses.text: From the city he took an officer who was in charge of the men of war, and five men who were among the king’s counselors, and the commander of the army who drafted the people of the land, and sixty men from the city who were found in the city.
verses.comment: Recension difference: Jeremiah lists seven counselors, Kings five—note maintained per source.

verses.text: Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard took these and brought them to the king of Babylon at Riblah.
verses.comment: Faithful to transport details.

verses.text: And the king of Babylon struck them down and put them to death at Riblah in the land of Hamath. So Judah was taken away from its land into exile.
verses.comment: Concludes the deportation with exile statement.

verses.text: Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon appointed Gedaliah son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan, to be governor over the people who remained in the land of Judah.
verses.comment: Retains governor’s lineage and position.

verses.text: When all the captains of the armies and their men heard that the king of Babylon had appointed Gedaliah as governor, they came to Gedaliah at Mizpah—namely, Ishmael son of Nethaniah, Johanan son of Kareah, Seraiah son of Tanhumeth the Netophathite, and Jaazaniah son of the Maacathite—each with his men.
verses.comment: Names and order preserved; 'captains' as in Hebrew.

verses.text: Gedaliah swore to them and to their men, saying, ‘Do not be afraid of the servants of the Chaldeans. Dwell in the land and serve the king of Babylon, and it will go well with you.’
verses.comment: Direct speech for accuracy.

verses.text: But in the seventh month, Ishmael son of Nethaniah, son of Elishama, of the royal family, came with ten men and struck down Gedaliah. He died, and also the Jews and the Chaldeans who were with him at Mizpah.
verses.comment: Specifics of assassination maintained.

verses.text: Then all the people, both small and great, and the captains of the armies, arose and went to Egypt, for they were afraid of the Chaldeans.
verses.comment: 'Small and great' as in original; fleeing route clear.

verses.text: In the thirty-seventh year of the exile of Jehoiachin king of Judah, in the twelfth month, on the twenty-seventh day of the month, Evil-merodach king of Babylon, in the year he became king, released Jehoiachin king of Judah from prison.
verses.comment: 'Released' as 'lifted up the head of' Jehoiachin.

verses.text: He spoke kindly to him and gave him a seat above the seats of the kings who were with him in Babylon.
verses.comment: Shows Jehoiachin’s favor and elevated status.

verses.text: So Jehoiachin put off his prison garments, and he ate regularly at the king’s table all the days of his life.
verses.comment: Prison to royal status shift highlighted.

verses.text: And for his allowance, a regular portion was given him by the king, every day, all the days of his life.
verses.comment: Retained precise daily allowance per original.
